organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

title.gco:CharacterString: 1:1,000,000-Scale National Boundaries of the United States, 2014

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: These data were downloaded from the National Atlas website (http://www.nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp.html) in August 2014.

collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This polygon shapefile contains the boundaries of the United States, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. The map layer was created by extracting county polygon features from the 2006 Census TIGER/Line files produced by the U.S. Census Bureau. These files were then merged into a single file and the county and State boundaries were dissolved, leaving the national boundary. This is a revised version of the July 2012 map layer. This layer is part of the 1997-2014 edition of the National Atlas of the United States.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: These data are intended for geographic display and analysis at the national level, and for large regional areas. The data should be displayed and analyzed at scales appropriate for 1:1,000,000-scale data. No responsibility is assumed by the National Atlas of the United States in the use of these data.

credit.gco:CharacterString: U.S. Geological Survey. (2014). 1:1,000,000-Scale National Boundaries of the United States, 2014. USGS. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/hb541mt8292

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions about this map layer or metadata, please contact the National Atlas using the information above, or through the U.S. Geological Survey contact page at http://www.usgs.gov/ask/. For distribution questions, please see the Distribution Information elsewhere in this metadata.

useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: None. Acknowledgment of The National Atlas of the United States of America would be appreciated in products derived from these data.

Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the U.S. Geological Survey regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.

title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.3.1.4959

title.gco:CharacterString: Feature catalog for 1:1,000,000-Scale National Boundaries of the United States, 2014

evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: The map layer was checked for topological consistency using ArcGIS. No other checks for logical consistency were performed on this map layer.

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: The map layer was checked for topological consistency using ArcGIS. No other checks for logical consistency were performed on this map layer.
This map layer includes national boundaries for the 50 States, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

description.gco:CharacterString: The 1:1,000,000-scale county boundaries were extracted from U.S. Census TIGER (Topologically Integrated Geographic Encoding and Reference system) data. The TIGER files were merged and generalized. County and State boundaries within the national boundary were removed using the ESRI dissolve tool.

All the 1:1,000,000-scale map layers were checked for vertical integration. Line positions were adjusted as necessary to remove overlaps. Wherever possible, linear features were separated by 300 meters, but were kept within 500 meters of their true location.

The areas in the file were combined into large polygons, one representing the conterminous United States including associated islands, one representing Alaska, one representing Hawaii, one representing the U.S. Virgin Islands, one representing Puerto Rico, and one representing the Great Lakes. Population values were added from the 2010 Census information. The data were projected by region to the National Atlas Albers Equal Area Conic projection, fields were added for the perimeter measurement and square miles, the values were calculated using ArcMap, and the data were converted back to geographic coordinates. The Albers Equal Area Conic parameters used are available on request.
The map layer was saved in shapefile and in file geodatabase formats.

Data along the Canadian border were adjusted so that the Canadian and U.S. 1:1,000,000-scale data sets can be used together as seamlessly as possible. Problem areas were identified by Natural Resources Canada (NRCan) and edits to the U.S. data were performed by the USGS. To identify problems, the National Atlas 1M national boundaries 2012 data set was projected to the NRCan working coordinate system, which is a Lambert Conformal Conic projection with standard parallels of 49 and 77 degrees, datum of NAD83, an XY tolerance of 0.001 meters, and an XY resolution of 0.0001 meters. The Canadian and U.S. data sets were displayed together and features were compared across the border. An initial set of comments and suggestions for edits were sent to the USGS by NRCan. NRCan used satellite imagery for reference during the editing process by converting the appropriate National Atlas 1:1,000,000-scale map layers and the 250K Canadian topographic data to KML and loading the KMLs into GoogleEarth. Using the cursor coordinates in the ArcMap status bar, NRCan visually navigated and correlated the ArcMap and GoogleEarth vectors. NRCan exported their findings and sent them to the USGS for correction and (or) further comment. USGS reviewed the Canadian findings and returned the data to NRCan with comments. The U.S. data were either edited, not edited and further explanation was requested, or not edited and changes were suggested for the Canadian data. This process was repeated until both NRCan and USGS felt that the data were satisfactorily harmonized.

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Government of Canada, Natural Resources Canada, Geomatics Canada, Surveyor General's Branch, International Boundary Commission

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Updated and converted from NAD27 to NAD83 boundary monument coordinates.

title.gco:CharacterString: 1:1,000,000-Scale National Atlas map layers and other quality control files

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Numerous sources were used to perform quality-control and vertical integration, including all the 1:1,000,000-scale National Atlas map layers, a variety of online sources, and printed USGS topographic maps. More information is available from the National Atlas contacts listed elsewhere in this metadata.
